The plastic wheel just busted, which is why I'm writing this review now.  Prior to that, this thing never rolled very good.  I had to lift myself out of the chair and push with some force to get myself around.  Yes, people who sit in computer chairs can likely use exercise... but it's not supposed to be like this.  The wheels are very bad.The arm rests were fair at best.  Too little padding.  And yes, they got a little loose.It was quite comfortable from the start.  But within a few days, I was online buying a back rest.  The headrest was a must have for me and this was "ok" - but not great.  Feels cheap and wobbles.  But your head doesn't need that much support, so it worked.  But it wasn't really well thought out.  So within a few days... I bought a headrest pad to attach (via a strap) so that I didn't have to throw my head so far back to relax my neck.But the chair with these simple, cheap mods, was ok -- especially since the chair was only $200.  That was my plan from the start.The seat padding.  It was great at first.  But I can feel it starting to go -- and the hard base is starting to feel through.  But it's still fine.  So overall I can't complain.  Yet.  The chair is only a year old.  If I had this chair for two years (I won't) then I might be singing a different tune.  Another thing -- it's heavy.  Very heavy.  More than I thought anyway.I gave it two stars (would be three if the wheel didn't just bust!) because this thing -- with my modifications -- was light years better than my chair at the office -- which has no head rest and the worst back support I've ever had.  So, this chair was heaven to sit in after work.  But with it only lasting a year -- because of its questionable construction and design issues -- I have to knock it down a bit.  I thought I'd get 3 or 4 years out of it.  Nope.It was only $200 and I didn't expect $1,000 quality.  I knew going in that spending only $200 for instrument that has such a crucial job as holding you up and supporting you for hours -- that I'd be buying another chair soon.  And here I am.I'm done with cheap chairs.
This is the same product I ordered over a year ago but it seems like half the thickness.Believe the reviews. I should have.The thickness of a cheap index card.

Beware this printer if you only have a Chromebook.  In order to get this printer to print via the cloud, you have to first connect it to a PC and update the firmware.  For someone like me, who only has the Chromebook and no other tech available, this is not a possibility.Here is an excerpt from the end of my lengthy customer service live chat with Samsung this morning:Kevin P: Have you updated the firmware from the Samsung website through a windows PC?Visitor: no. I don't have a windows pc. I have a chromebook.Kevin P: As we are unable to print from cloud printing, we need to update the firmware and we need a windows PC to update the firmware of the printer to print wirelessly from cloud printing.Visitor: so Samsung sold me a "cloud ready" printer advertised to work with my specific laptop that is not, in fact, cloud ready, and will not, in fact, work with my laptop without the presence of an additional computer?Kevin P: I understand your concern, we need an additional computer only to setup the wireless cloud printing on the printer.Kevin P: Once we setup the printer, we print wirelessly without any additional computer.Visitor: well, I have no other computer. Are there no other options for me?Kevin P: I am afraid, there are no options available as we are getting the error message while trying to print wirelessly and we need to upgrade the firmware using a windows PC to solve the issue.So there you have it folks.  If you have another machine kicking around to help you set this up, you will probably be fine.  One star from me for all of the headache and hassle plus one, to be fair, because it does print using the USB cable.  This one was a pity for me, since it was light and compact and I liked the look of it otherwise.

Product: 1 star  Seller:4  stars  (wish I could give product 0 stars)Chair arrived about June. Opened box and one caster wheel was missing, and the plastic bag that holds the casters was cut open. Looks like someone grabbed a caster from the box. I told seller and they sent out a replacement caster. I would purchased from them again.Took 2 hours to get chair together, most of the time was spent on getting the back attached to the bottom. Had to lie on top of the arms to get the screws to line up into the holes in the back and front. When done the back didn't line up with the stripes on the bottom.I noticed right away that there was no way the back would go straight up and down. When a person sat in it and leaned back a little there was a noticable "ding" sound coming from the chair shaft whenever a person sat up straight. Also when a person stood up there was a banging sound, pretty distracting in a quiet office.October 2017, about 3 months after the chair was put into use the chair fell apart. A screw came out of the right side and the chair does not have not have an upright back anymore. I might just chuck this in the trash. Without notice the chair will lean backwards even if the option bar has selected the upright position.IT IS A SAFETY hazard if you get one of these for an employee in your office.I now have to start again from scratch looking for an office chair. Between the assembly and the problems I will probably NOT shop on line for a replacement.

The moment one of my cats jump up onto it, there would be crashing as the laptop fell to the floor, and a freaked out cat zooming out of the room when the table it expected to be sturdy, moved with the slightest weight. No way in *** would this hold even 10lbs.  Some of the holes the adjusting knobs screw into are already stripping because they're plastic! I should have paid more attention to the negative reviews & not so much on the positive ones that seemed to make the negative reviewers look bad.

I bought this slide scanner (on January 9, 2013) on the basis of other Amazon reviews. Received it promptly (as Amazon always does!), installed it according to the directions, and started scanning some of our hundreds of slides (almost all Kodachrome) from some years back. Viewing the slides on a slide sorter device showed them to be totally intact in color and lighting. When I began scanning them on the Veho scanner, however, the colors were badly distorted to the warm side, the lighting allowed for flaring (too bright on objects in the foreground),and focus/sharpness was lacking. Now, I bought this scanner because of its speed which is great. Then I scanned the same slides with my good old Epson scanner which is much slower, and found that the colors, lighting, focus, etc. were a faithful rendition of the slides themselves. Thus, I decided to return this device (Veho VFS-002m) to Amazon for a refund. Perhaps I just received a poor quality unit, but since I'm retired I decided I will just have to take the time to scan my slides with my old Epson. If anybody knows of any other faster slide scanners I'd appreciate knowing about it. I don't really want to spend hundreds of dollars for a unit, though.

Running Mac OSX. Wifi setup was difficult. Computer wouldn't see the printer on the network. Had to plug in via USB find and install manually. Also, the printer spontaneously stops communicating with any computer in the house. Says "unable to find printer" in the print dialogue box. If I uninstall and reinstall printer drivers it begins working again. Print quality is good and printer is fast when working, but very inconsistent. Seems that it may be unique to Mac environment, because I've seen some other similar reviews from Mac users.

There may be worse printers out there, you are better off trying something else because it is hard to do worse than this. It gets one star since amazon doesn’t allow for zero stars.1. The device can be accessed via USB or WIFI. It makes for an expensive USB printer but that is the the most reliable method.2. The WiFi networking sucks. Sometimes it will appear on the network and we can print for a few days. The rest of the time the answer is to move whatever document to the laptop and use USB.3. The support and documentation suck harder than the terrible WiFi. HP “supports” this device which means that you get punted to HP’s website which gives some generic advice on multiple Samsung devices at once.If you’d like to recreate the Office Space scene, Amazon will sell you a baseball bat too. That is the only thing this printer is good for.

Summary: Could be very good, but marred by repeated spooling and printhead problems.I replaced a broken Canon all-in-one I'd been very satisfied with. I was initially attracted by the features and low ink cost.The inherent pros and cons, before the problems I'll describe below, are:PRO:1. Very low black and white ink cost. (Color ink is no bargain.) Additional free cartridges if you buy from Lexmark's online store.2. Duplex (two-sided) printing quality as good as simplex. The Canon all-in-ones lighten the print to a grayish tone when you request duplex, to avoid smearing the ink or getting it on the inside rollers.3. The touch screen user interface is well-designed.4. The included ABBYY OCR software is very accurate.5. Five-year warranty, if you register online.CON:1. No duplex *scanning* (the higher end Canons do this).2. No alternate paper feed. If I load a single sheet of thicker photo paper on top of regular 24lb inkjet paper, the paper picker invariably picks up two sheets. I must remove any other paper before loading photo paper. In addition, very thick photo paper does not make the sharp U-turn inside the printer easily, and I may get banding due to misalignment.3. Paper tray is difficult to close.4. The TWAIN control panel has a limited number of settings, compared with, say, the Canon equivalent.5. PDF scanning produces uncompressed PDF files, which are very large, even for bitonal (B&W) scans. I bought an inexpensive third-party product, Softi ScanWiz, to get around this problem.6. Scanning to different types of files when using "Advanced Scan..." is not intuitive. After scanning, you give a filename in which to save the scan. Depending on the file type (.jpg, .txt, etc.), different software will be run. For instance, choosing a .txt file will run the OCR software.Now the problems:SPOOLING FAILURES:On both Windows 7 32-bit and 64-bit, on two different computers, print jobs sometimes stop spontaneously before completion. The progress bar displayed on-screen stops progressing. Any further printing attempts just queue up. The usual cure is to start a Command Prompt, right-clicking to "Run as administrator", and then do "NET STOP SPOOLER", and "NET START SPOOLER". Occasionally even this does not work and I must reboot. I have reinstalled and updated the drivers and firmware faithfully, to no avail. This problem happens irregularly several times a week.I have had multiple exchanges with Lexmark tech support about this, and recently had an on-line remote-access tech-support session, which found no issues that could be causing this problem. Later I found Lexmark knowledgebase article SO6683 (search on the Lexmark site), which describes the lxec_device stopping spontaneously. That's what's happening to me.PRINTHEAD FAILURES:Printhead issues are described repeatedly in other Amazon reviews. After about six months of initial satisfactory use, I started having wide swathes of cyan ink on printouts. Lexmark very readily sent me a new printhead and a new set of ink cartridges. Printing was fine for a couple of months, but now I find that after only a day or less of non-use, yellow and cyan do not print unless I do a printhead cleaning first. I probably need yet another new printhead.At this point, I am researching new printers. I have asked Lexmark for my money back or to replace the printer with one of their brand new comparable Pro915 or Pro715 printers. These new models have new cartridge part numbers and presumably a newer printhead design. Lexmark's tech support is responsive, and they are honoring the five year warranty, but it's clear there is an inherent design flaw in this printer. Interestingly, the new Pro915 and Pro715 have only 1-year warranties.

I did a lot of review-reading as I got ready to purchase a new PDA. I had a windows-based PDA that was okay but too expensive to replace. The Palm TX had great reviews in a lot of places. Basically, I need to look at documents, use some medical software, take notes, and occasionally surf the web. The Palm TX seemed like the best option. But after purchasing it, I was unhappy. The handheld is slim, but the protecting case is difficult to apply and wasn't adequate for protecting it (adding another case, like I did, added to the bulk). In addition, the handheld froze frequently, necessitating multiple soft resets. I figured that if it was going to do that within a week, it wasn't worth keeping. I returned it and bought an ipod touch, with which I am VERY happy.
I was mislead by all the positive reviews that these sketchbooks received. The paper is only suitable for light doodles not for pens or markers as they easily bleed through.

Wait, then why did I rate them two stars? THE SHIPPING! These bins are shipped ASSEMBLED and stacked - taking up about 3x as much space as opposed to stacking them with the lids off. It is dumb and nonsensical. It’s been like this for over a year (edit: 4 years), when I began buying these things by the dozen. What this awful shipping translates to is this:Higher product price or shipping price.Lower Prime availability.Longer shipping times.Increased chance of shipping damage (I have had two incidents) (edit: 4), not only because the box is bigger but the bins have greater durability when stacked inside each other.Also there is never any packaging inside the box.Fix the shipping!!As for the bins themselves - great bins. Very modular, clear, easily washable (may warp in the dishwasher), decently water resistant, fit paper perfectly. Will probably crack if you drop it. I take a pair of snips and cut off all the alignment tabs that keep the lids together when they’re stacked, that way I can fill the bins higher.Edit: it's been like 4 years since I started buying these, and I've amassed at least 60. They still haven't fixed the shipping, and that goes for any size of this type of bin. Even Walmart receives them stacked, I've seen them unloading. I don't understand. Oh well... if you are a organizational perfectionist, these are the bins for you.Also, I realized the "alignment tabs" are actually just remnants of the plastic extrusion process, they don't align anything. There's no harm in cutting them off! Use flush cutters. The plastic does usually get hairline cracks when you do this but I haven't had any problems or broken lids from it, even with 4 year old bins that I frequently drop. You could probably cut and sand them with a Dremel if you're worried about cracks. Kind of obnoxious they leave them at this price point. Finally, expect the exact color of the clips to change, I have a few distinct blues over the years despite always buying the same one. Target has green ones.
I'd rate this higher but it's of no use to a machine that won't work.

I purchased these poly mailers against my husband's advice and I have to admit it was a huge mistake. These are way thinner than I anticipated (which was my mistake I should have read the description) so I'm not sure how well they will hold up during transit. They also smell dreadful (think of plastic mixed with ash tray or someone smoked into it). I guess you get what you pay for as I purchased these for the quantity/price versus the usual ValueMailers Poly Mailers my husband orders for me. To clarify the two star rating - Even though they disclosed the thickness (so I can't really complain that they are thin), they did, however, describe the item as "durable, professional, private and secure". The material itself does not make me think of any of those descriptions as I had to throw away my first poly mailer because my nail scratched through it! I'm sure they are good for what they are if you are mailing something small or simple or maybe even one item of small or very thin clothing but like I stated before I don't know how well it would hold up going through the mail system. I will not be ordering these again.

If I could give this sharpener 0 stars, I would. I was surprised by the nearly all positive reviews posted, but I would have been fairly positive before mine broke after about 40 days.  I used an m515 for years with no problems and liked the TX for its improved screen, color, memory, and mp3 capabilities.  In short, it was time to upgrade to a modern product.But after 40 days in which the on/off switch seemed to work intermittently, it failed altogether and I had to send it back to Palm for repair.  LET THE BUYER BEWARE that if your TX fails, you will send it at your own expense to Palm for repair.  So if a 10% increase in your overall cost is ok, as well as doing without your device for a week or two, then this thing might be ok.  But for me, a product that fails at all has already earned a bad review, and the manufacturer should own up to the responsibility of having sold defective merchandise and, for the sake of their reputation, should bear all costs for the repair.  So this alone warrants a poor rating from me and in fact I will never buy another Palm product.From comments posted elsewhere, both on this site and on the Palm support site, I gather that there have been a lot of devices sold with this defective on/off switch.  I have also read about broken screens and frequent device resets, though I haven't experienced that (yet).  The TX is incompatible with a couple of applications I have with the older m515.One of my major interests in the device was as an mp3 player, reasoning that with an add-on 4GB memory card it would be comparable to an ipod nano but also have the Palm OS.  I asked Palm support if a 4 GB card would work and they responded that they had not tested any.  I believe this answer to be baloney, but if not it's a poor report on Palm anyway.  I found out elsewhere that the TX is one of two Palm devices supporting FAT32 drives and would therefore work with large memory cards, so I bought one and it does in fact work just fine.  I suspect Palm won't tell anybody this because it would undercut sales of their more expensive and ill-considered LifeDrive.

Just know that I am a little ticked that I have to give it one star, because it doesn't even deserve that.Here is my story. I get this thing from a friends mother who won it in a contest. It was brand new. Was given to me for my birthday.I have been building and working with PC's for over 12 years now, and never in my life have I used a worse printer. This thing was garbage from the start. Here is what I encountered with this thing:- First off, there are two installations that you do at the same time, the one on the PC, and the one on the printer itself.-Never printed anything. Would load the paper, try to test print, and it would give me an error that there is no paper in the tray. There clearly is.-Upon further inspection, and trying to get the paper in the right spot, I try again only for it to tell me that there is a paper jam._Frustrated, I pull the paper out and try to get it in there good. Try and print and get an error (0x000161 or some thing like that) and now I have to power it off and on again. Mind you I am still in the setup phase. About 20 minutes have passed. Getting very frustrated.-Reset the machine, forced to go thru the ENTIRE setup again, which requires me to answer a ton of questions about where I live and stuff. Was getting asked all of this from the printer. That was a first. By the way, the touch screen is not as cool as it looks. It is actually quite cheap and doesnt respond to touch very well.-Finally get the machine back to the test print page. At this point I have wasted about 45 minutes. I am on the test print just on the printer, have not even got to the part where I install the drivers. I try the test again and SUCCESS! IT PRINTED OU..... wait. What? Why is the printer throwing blank paper out after the print? I power it down to stop since the machine does not have the red X displayed to cancel. Says it is powering down, yet continues to throw paper out. Figure it is a phase. After about 100 sheets thrown at me, I have to pull the power cord to make it stop. Great.... Time to start the initial setup AGAIN! FROM THE BEGINNING!- Give up. Wait till morning. I go to store and buy all new paper. I figure I should at least try that.- Does not work. Paper is either "missing from main tray", paper is "jammed", or error 0x0001662e or something like that pops up. Finally prints a page without any problems (though I used just one piece and fed it into the printer by hand). It has now been a day and a half, and I have not even installed the drivers, but I will finally get to now!- thinking I just fixed whatever issue the printer was having, I go to install the drivers. Not only do I get the drivers, but I also get all this other bloatware installed on my PC! Thanks Hp for giving me shit that I never ever wanted....- Get the drivers installed. It has been two days and I feel that I am finally done. I test it by printing from the PC. No success. All the issues previously stated are occurring. Still.- Try all over again, in quick mode. Does not work. Gave up. Boxed the machine back up. About to take it to the garage with my baseball bat. Give the damn thing some Office Space treatment.Overall I spent about 3 days trying to get this printer to do the simplest task its made to do, print. It failed in every way possible. This thing was a disaster from the start, so bad that I never got to use it once. Maybe I am one lucky SOB, but this is the first time that I have had a product let me down as much as this printer did. Worst of all, it was a gift, from a prize win, so there is no return. Who would want it back anyway? Needless to say, do not buy this product. It is hot garbage. A waste of money. Lies about stating it is a printer when it is actually a potato. Potatoes do not print, they are potatoes.**  TO ANY HP EMPLOYEE THAT MAY READ THIS: YOUR PRODUCTS HAVE SLIPPED SO POORLY THAT HP WILL BECOME THE FIRST COMPANY THAT I WILL NEVER BUY FROM AGAIN. I GIVE ALL COMPANIES CHANCES, BUT YOUR COMPANY HAS SHAVED TIME OFF MY LIFE WITH THE STRESS FROM YOUR ONE PRODUCT. I WILL STEER CLEAR OF ANY AND ALL HP PRODUCTS, AS WELL AS ALL PRODUCTS THAT JUST BARE THE HP LOGO. YOU HAVE COMPLETELY LOST ONE CUSTOMER. FOREVER.

I'm so disappointed with Strathmore. I've bought their cards in the past and pulled out some old work to compare when i noticed how awful this product was.  The old product was classic 140 pound cold press texture.  This one... well-- just wait until you actually put paint on the paper.  It dries into a weird texture that looks like corduroy material (see image.  Zoom in). Every single card in my 100 count box has this awful kind of tilted cord texture. It doesn't absorb water,  the water just floats until it's murky. The pigments won't blend.  It reminds me of years ago when I had a case of half sheets that were run over by a truck.  Literally tire tread marks appeared in the paint.  That's exactly what this looks like but with tiny little treads everywhere. The problem with these mailers is that they are not the dimensions advertised when you fold the flap.  When you fold the flap, you get a 6 x 6 mailer.  Not 6 x 6 3/8.  The problem with square mailers is that they are subject to a postal surcharge because the machine readers need an oblong format.Here is what USPS says: "Letters that meet one or more of the nonmachinable characteristics below are subject to the nonmachinable surcharge. It is a square letter or The length divided by height is less than 1.3 or more than 2.5."The result is that what you can ship your disks for depends on your local post office. If they allow it, you get the low rate.  If not, there is a surcharge or you'll have to pay parcel post rates which are considerably higher.  Ergo, postage for this 6 x 6 folded size is arbitrary.  So if you are going to use these, pack a sample and take it to your postmaster.  Have it sized and weighed and get a rate.

In the other cases where I have compared DeLorme & Benchmark side by side (California, New Mexico, Arizona), I prefer DeLorme.  Not this time.  As other reviewers have mentioned, BLM land is not marked in the main body of the atlas, only in the whole-state map; this alone makes the atlas nearly useless for those interested in exploring public lands.  Benchmark's marking of public lands at a coarse scale in their "recreation maps", but not in the finer scale "landscape maps" is not ideal, but it is workable; DeLorme's approach for Nevada is not.  I also notice that Benchmark includes more campgrounds (including one I stayed at last summer south of Silver Springs) and other fine detail for Nevada than DeLorme, whereas in other cases the opposite is true.  Elsewhere in the west, stick with DeLorme.  For Nevada, get the Benchmark.

I have several fountain pens, including a Waterman sterling silver cartridge model that I got a few years ago as an anniversary gift from my employers (as a large, faceless bureaucracy, they took no part in the selection).I use this one whenever I need to sign documents in blue ink - probably once every couple of months, on average, but a lot of documents at a time, for real estate transactions, and using a ball-point puts too much strain on my fingers.Because the Waterman cartridges dry out so quickly, I have to use a new cartridge every time, which is (a) an annoyance, and (b) an outrageous expense in terms of value for money (and yes, I can afford the few dollars I shell out every year or so). This printer works as a normal printer/scanner/copier, BUT has HP software limitations that makes the E-Printing almost useless!  I will break this review into three sections; 1st e-printing, 2nd customer support, and 3rd regular printer functions (printer, scanner, & copier).1.  E-Printing: 1 out of 5 starsNEGATIVE - HP software only allows you to send your photo to ONE printer.  If you send the photo to two or more printers at once, no one gets the photo.  So if you are interested in sending photos to several relatives or friends on a regular basis then currently HP printers are not the product for you.NEGATIVE - HP server limits emails to 5 MB size.  So double check your file size of your photos.  We have two point and shoot cameras, one is 5 megapixels & other is 10 megapixels. Using these cameras we can only send 1-2 photos per email.  We also have a digital DSL camera, but most of our RAW files are over 5 MB and need to have the file size reduced to work with HP limits.2.  Customer Support: 0 out of 5 starsNEGATIVE - Spent 40 minutes on the phone being jumped from department to department on HP's customer service line to be told that HP does not have any customer support set up for USA, only for international services....3.  Regular Printer Functions: 5 out of 5 starsPositive - Printer quality is great, the photo quality matches what you get from stores.  Scanner & copier both work, but have lower resolution than printer output.

Sent me a 2nd full set of cartridges, including two new black ones.  I spent 7 hours yesterday trying to make this work.  Apparently, the black ink is a known problem - HP does something to make it not work - other colors work just fine.  Too bad - wanted something far less expensive than the HP ink.  Company was very, very helpful and followed up - it's really HP's fault.  I don't know what would happen if I bought an HP black cartridge - not sure I want to spend more money to find out if that would "fix" the problem, or if the non-HP ink ruined the printhead.
